title: WHATWG-relevant MDN issues
description: Issue filed on MDN Web Docs related to pages attached to technologies developed by WHATWG

items.content_html:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/input

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

/Web/HTML/Element/input/*

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The <input type="*"> pages are missing information about their implied ARIA role.

The implicit ARIA roles are describes on the <input>, which is good. Unfortunately, if a reader doesn't think to go up a level, they won't have access to this information.

What did you expect to see?

There's a table on each input type page. I expect implied ARIA role to be one of those rows.

Value A string representing the value contained in the search field.
Events {{domxref("HTMLElement/change_event", "change")}} and {{domxref("HTMLElement/input_event", "input")}}
Supported Common Attributes {{htmlattrxref("autocomplete", "input")}}, {{htmlattrxref("list", "input")}}, {{htmlattrxref("maxlength", "input")}}, {{htmlattrxref("minlength", "input")}}, {{htmlattrxref("pattern", "input")}}, {{htmlattrxref("placeholder", "input")}}, {{htmlattrxref("required", "input")}}, {{htmlattrxref("size", "input")}}.
IDL attributes value
Implicit ARIA roles
  • with no list attribute: {{ARIARole("searchbox")}}
  • with list attribute:{{ARIARole("combobox")}}
DOM interface

{{domxref("HTMLInputElement")}}
Methods {{domxref("HTMLInputElement.select", "select()")}}, {{domxref("HTMLInputElement.setRangeText", "setRangeText()")}}, {{domxref("HTMLInputElement.setSelectionRange", "setSelectionRange()")}}.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

Input page
Example Input Type page (one of many)

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

items.content_html:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/ErrorEvent

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/ErrorEvent#instance_properties

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

When a script is included from a URL different from where it is executed the error.message is truncated for security reasons. However this is not documented except on crossorigin, which is not where developers will be looking with an error problem.

What did you expect to see?

I would expect or at least hope to see the things that affect error.message on the related error page where the message is discussed.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

The https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Attributes/crossorigin page says in the default section that lack of a crossorgin setting reduces error logging.

script Access to error logging via window.onerror will be limited.

The same info should be on a page about error.message

Do you have anything more you want to share?

Javascript errors are a little complicated and difficult to document clearly, there is not a reason to include this in the error documentation since it will help developers find what they need in the most likely place to look for it.
items.title: [html] ErrorEvent should document that ErrorEvent.message depends on 'HTML attribute: crossorigin'

items.content_html:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/dialog

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

The Advanced example section

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The <dialog> element has a strange behavior. If you close the dialog using the Escape key or a button without a value attribute then the returnValue property is left unchanged. Any dialog close event handler that relies on the returnValue to determine which button was clicked can easily come to the wrong conclusion.

Steps to reproduce the problem in the example given on this page.

  1. Click the Update details button.
  2. Click Confirm. You will see the message default button clicked.
  3. Click the Update details button again.
  4. Hit Esc key to close the dialog.
  5. The message will incorrectly show default button clicked. The timestamp will be updated.

This is a most unusual behavior for the <dialog> element that borders on being a defect. In any case, the documentation needs to point this out. One way to work around this issue is to reset the returnValue to undefined before opening the dialog. For example:

favDialog.returnValue = undefined;
favDialog.showModal();

Now, when you close the dialog using the Esc key the returnValue will be undefined.

You can also define the cancel button without a value.

<button>Cancel</button>

Now the cancel button and the Esc key will behave the same way. That is, they will close the dialog with the returnValue set to undefined.

What did you expect to see?

The effect of the Esc key or a button without a value on returnValue needs to be discussed. Almost any use of a dialog is vulnerable to defect unless this issue is addressed correctly.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

No response

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

items.content_html:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/fr/docs/Web/API/Document/activeElement

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Document.activeElement

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

Hello,

The introduction of the article (and the entire content) is totally focused on input elements.

The most common cases

Often activeElement will return a HTMLInputElement or HTMLTextAreaElement object.

However, in the major operating systems (OS) and browsers (I tested only on 4), the HTMLAnchorElement (A element) is focusable.

In the era of accessibility, for those who navigate with the keyboard, and for all those (everybody) who click on a link (A or an internal anchor #) : the focus is triggered and the Document.activeElement returns anHTMLAnchorElement.

And there are often more links (A links) in a page than input elements. (N.B. see examples in last part of this issue content).

This can be confusing, when you see yourself that the majority of the elements not mentioned in the article take the focus by default, in general.

The case of macOS

There is an exception on macOS (which is specified in the article), but by looking for information about Document.activeContent, it seems to me that more explanations can be provided.

Which elements are focusable varies depending on the platform and the browser's current configuration. For example, on macOS systems, elements that aren't text input elements are not typically focusable by default.

This is true, but a clarification can be added : on macOS only some browsers take into account the default configuration of the operating system : Safari and Chrome do, but Firefox and Microsoft Edge do not. (N.B. see examples in last part of this issue content).

This last information can be confusing when looing for information about Document.activeElement. Indeed, with the default macOS configuration, if when testing on Chome the A elements are not focusable but when testing on Firefox they are, the article does not really open your eyes to the macOS configuration (which is not taken into account by at least half of the browsers).

What did you expect to see?

It can be expected the HTMLAnchorElement to be referenced as a focusable element.
Alternatively, the sentence the "Often activeElement will return a HTMLInputElement or HTMLTextAreaElement object" could be modified to explain the context of this specification. The writer(s) are probably thinking of the use of Document.activeElement in the listener of a FocusEvent whose target would be a HTMLInputElement or a HTMLTextareaElement, but as a developer it is interesting to have a more global view.

Of course, the precision regarding macOS should be retained, but perhaps adding that "some elements are not typically focusable by default" is also browser dependent on macOS (regardeless the configuration). This could avoid extensive research into why it works on one browser but not the other.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

No response

Do you have anything more you want to share?

For example, on the page Document.activeElement, by counting focusable elements.

Most common cases

The HTMLAnchorElement are focusable on Linux, on Windows and on macOS (with the keyboard setting "Use keyboard navigation to move focus between controls"), and it seems that this is for all browsers :

Brower HTMLAnchorElement HTMLButtonElement HTMLInputElement
Firefox/Edge/Chrome/Safari 215 15 1

The case of macOS

On macOS, with default OS configuration (without the keyboard setting "Use keyboard navigation to move focus between controls" so) :

Brower  HTMLAnchorElement HTMLButtonElement HTMLInputElement
Firefox 215 15 1
Microsoft Edge 215 15 1
Chome 0 15 1
Safari 0 0 1
items.title: [html, uievents] Document.activeElement : The lack of HTMLAnchorElement and macOS on a case by case basis

items.content_html:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Global_attributes/tabindex

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

"Check out this fiddle to understand the scrolling effects of tabindex."

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

When viewing the JS fiddle, the first div says: "Child(orange background div)'s content can NOT be accessed by scrolling with Keyboard"

Tabbing into it, the first tab stop highlights the child (orange background div) which shows a focus ring around it. Using the keyboard does indeed scroll the content of the inner/orange background div. [Though, the message says "Child (orange background div)'s content can NOT be accessed by scrolling with the keyboard", though I can scroll the child element fine]

I cannot however focus the outer (white background) div that contains it, or scroll that div with the keyboard, unless I click within that div with my mouse, then I can scroll the outer div, which makes the next tab stop the inner div again, which I can still scroll with the keyboard.

Starting over (keyboard only, ie. disregarding my mouse focus mentioned in the previous paragraph), the next (second) tab stop on the page is the inner div of the second container; this results in the same behavior as the first (outer can't be scrolled unless mouse focused, inner scrolls with keyboard). [I suppose the label here isn't wrong]

Continuing down the page, the third tab stop is the third outer div, which I can scroll with the keyboard. Next stop is the inner div of the same third outer div, which I can also scroll with keyboard. [Again, label not really wrong I guess]

Fourth box (which is the 5th tab stop) selects the outer div, which I can scroll with keyboard, tabbing again doesn't select the inner div, thus I cannot scroll the inner div with keyboard. [Label here says I can scroll the child, but I can't]

Fifth box (6th tab stop) selects the fifth boxes outer div, which I can scroll with keyboard. Another tab selects it's child, which I can also scroll with keyboard. [Label here isn't wrong again I guess]

I should also note that the contrast between the fiddle saying "can [not] be accessed by scrolling with the keyboard" feels misleading as if focus should be changed by simply scrolling up/down with the keyboard alone, without any tabs; I'm not sure if that would be an accessibility option somewhere but even so, it contrasts with the description linking to the fiddle that says "its child content cannot be scrolled with the arrow keys" which also feels more accurate and clear.

Also, all the labels/descriptions on the page only refer to the inner div content being scrollable, there are situations (at least, now it seems) where the outer div also isn't scrollable and I wonder if it's worth mentioning/exemplifying that as well.

I'm not sure if behavior has changed since the creation of the fiddle or if behavior maybe varies between user agents; my testing on this was all done with Firefox 106.0.1 (64-bit) on Windows 10.

What did you expect to see?

The labels/descriptions matching the behavior (see above)

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

No response

Do you have anything more you want to share?

No response

items.content_html:
What type of issue is this?

Other

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

As you correctly link to the standard, replaceWith is a ChildNode mixin and not an Element method.

That means that even text nodes or comments can use replaceWith while not being instanceof Element.

This is rather a misleading link in MDN, but also changing it would kinda rot such misleading information, so something must change though, as the info is everything but reliable or accurate.

What browsers does this problem apply to, if applicable?

No response

What did you expect to see?

At least a link to ChildNode mixin, but also nothing strictly related to Element prototype.

Did you test this? If so, how?

document.createComment('').replaceWith ; // function
document.createComment('') instanceof Element; // false

Can you link to any release notes, bugs, pull requests, or MDN pages related to this?

https://dom.spec.whatwg.org/#interface-childnode

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The first paragraph of the page states that "The DOMContentLoaded event fires when the initial HTML document has been completely loaded and parsed, without waiting for stylesheets, images, and subframes to finish loading." I belive that this is partially incorrect. I have found out that preloading a large external stylesheet prevents a browser from firing DomContentLoaded event until the stylehsheet is parsed. I have tested this with Chrome browser. I will test this further with Firefox and update the issue.

What did you expect to see?

I am not certain if this is the only exception to the statement and thus not sure how to change the statement. However, there seems to be exceptions to the statement, and I belive that the exception as well as any other possibly known exceptions could be included in the document in order to avoid any potential confusion. The statement at least confused me.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

No response

Do you have anything more you want to share?

Steps to reproduce the situation

  1. create html file and preload a large external stylesheet. ex)
  2. Link the stylesheet. ex)
  3. Use vscode 'Live Server' extension to open the page
  4. Use a developer tool to find out when the DomContentLoaded event fires.

I have attached a screenshot of the event firing 2 seconds after the browser is done with parsing the html. The part ,that is highlighted in yellow line, indicates that the event was fired at 2.06s. The parsing of the html was finished long before the parsing of the external stylesheet began. The screenshot includes some korean words. Sorry for the inconvenience.

items.content_html:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Learn/JavaScript/Building_blocks/Events

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

  • Bubbling and capturing explained
  • Fixing the problem with stopPropagation()

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The high-level introduction to events in JavaScript contains some inaccurate statements that may confuse readers.

In the capturing phase:
The browser checks to see if the element's outer-most ancestor () has a click event handler registered on it for the capturing phase, and runs it if so.
Then it moves on to the next element inside and does the same thing, then the next one, and so on until it reaches the direct parent of the element that was actually clicked.

In the bubbling phase, the exact opposite of the capturing phase occurs:
The browser checks to see if the direct parent of the clicked element has a click event handler registered on it for the bubbling phase, and runs it if so.
Then it moves on to the next immediate ancestor element and does the same thing, then the next one, and so on until it reaches the element.

While it's true that all events proceed through both the capturing and bubbling phases, the event handlers are not guaranteed to run during both stages. The way that this section is phrased implies that all event handlers run twice: once during the capturing phase (top-down) and once again on the way back up. These sections also specifically discuss click event handlers when this should apply to all events.

The docs only clarify this point in the following paragraph:

In modern browsers, by default, all event handlers are registered for the bubbling phase. So in our current example, when you click the video, the event bubbles from the

It would be helpful to link to the Event.stopPropagation docs and rewrite this section to clarify how capturing/bubbling works more generally, specifically mentioning the third argument for addEventListener since it's what determines when the ancestor event handlers run: on the way down or on the way up.

There's also an issue in the following paragraph from the section titled Fixing the problem with stopPropagation():

As we saw in the video example, this can be a very annoying behavior, but there is a way to prevent it! The standard Event object has a function available on it called stopPropagation() which, when invoked on a handler's event object, makes it so that the first handler is run but the event doesn't bubble any further up the chain, so no more handlers will be run.

This is misleading because it suggests that stopPropagation only prevents bubbling. In reality, it can also prevent propagation to event handlers further down the tree in the capturing phase, depending on whether useCapture is true. The docs on Event.stopPropagation() clarify this, but it would be helpful to clarify it here as well since this is an introductory article.

What did you expect to see?

See notes above

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

The following MDN articles:

  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/EventTarget/addEventListener
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Event/stopPropagation

Do you have anything more you want to share?

Upon feedback/approval, I'd be happy to rewrite these sections. But I think the article may need a broader rewrite and perhaps new code samples (some of them, like the ones that involve clicking divs, are inaccessible to keyboard users—this may need to be filed as a separate issue).
items.title: [html, dom] "Introduction to events" article contains inaccurate/misleading statements

items.content_html:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/fetch

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Introduction and "Exceptions". At "Exceptions", the part about TypeError and the table listing all the reasons for it to happen. I didn't find anything that could justify my results in that list.

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

A fetch() promise only rejects when a network error is encountered (which is usually when there's a permissions issue or similar). A fetch() promise does not reject on HTTP errors (404, etc.). Instead, a then() handler must check the Response.ok and/or Response.status properties.

What did you expect to see?

I was expecting to trigger the execution of my success callback inside then() since http errors 4xx and 5xx should not reject the fetch promise. Instead, the error callback was executed.

It seems to me that the information in the fetch() and Fetch API pages are incorrect or outdated. I've made some tests and found that fetch is indeed rejecting promises when 400 status code is returned. I didn't try other error codes.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/45899931/typeerror-failed-to-fetch-trying-to-perform-an-post-request-on-api-hosted-on-he/72552340#72552340

https://forum.freecodecamp.org/t/type-error-failed-to-fetch-when-using-fetch-api/456214/5

Do you have anything more you want to share?

Here is my test:

  • Setup a server with some POST methods and respective OPTIONS methods to support preflight requests
  • Define some required field in the request body. If the request has the field, make your server return 200. Else, return 400.
  • Send a request with and without the field and check which callback is fired inside then().

Request code example:

  function test_fetch(){
	  let message = JSON.stringify({
             // 'ids' is the expected field. Change it latter for 'id' or something else to see the error.
             ids: [1] 
	  })
  
	  fetch('http://your.api/get_data',{
		  method: 'post',
                  // Adding Content-Type header to enable preflight. 
                  // It's still not working even with normal(no-preflight) requests.
                  // To test with normal instead of preflight requests,
                  // remove the line below from the fetch options object and
                  // make sure your server can handle text/plain data or else
                  // you may face some error due to wrong parsing of request body.
		  headers: {'Content-Type': 'application/json'},
		  body: message
	  })
	  .then(data => console.log('success'),data => console.log('error'))
  }

I've tested in Chrome, version 102.0.5005.61 (Official Build) (64-bit) and Firefox, version 75.0 (64-bit). Got the same unexpected behaviour in both.

items.content_html:
MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/HTMLImageElement/srcset

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

#value

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

To indicate that the image resource specified by the image candidate string should be used when the image is being rendered with a particular width in pixels, provide a width descriptor comprised the number giving that width in pixels followed by the lower case letter "w". For example, to provide an image resource to be used when the renderer needs a 450 pixel wide image, use the width descriptor string 450w. The specified width must be a positive, non-zero, integer, and must match the intrinsic width of the referenced image.

What did you expect to see?

Some text that would describe a more practical example. The text (set with bold) can give the wrong idea about how to use the srcset attribute.

The thing about the "width descriptor" is that it doesn't care about the actual rendered width of the image. The rule seems more to specify the width of the whole page than the actual rendered width of the image.

This is unless you specify the sizes attribute. Then you can specify a media condition followed by which width of the image you want to display. But this means, that it's possible to make rules about screen sizes, not rules to the actual rendered image size.

The text can be misleading making people think that the srcset is for network optimization in general when it actually (more or less) just seems more relevant for responsiveness.

A practical way of proving this is by the following.

<style>
    img {
        width: 50px;
    }
</style>
<img src="https://placehold.jp/50x50.png" 
     srcset="https://placehold.jp/150x150.png 50w,
             https://placehold.jp/150x150.png 150w,
             https://placehold.jp/2000x2000.png">

View it on jsfiddle

This very simple example will show a image that won't be wider than 50px at any time. But when this sample is viewed in a browser where the page is more than 150px wide, the 2000 x 2000 image will be the current source.
This has been tested on both Chrome 101 and Firefox 100.

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

No response

items.content_html:
What is the new suggestion?

I suggest to sort the properties list in the Sidebar for CSS pages by categories. That allows both looking for a property that one forgot the exact name of, if you still know what it's for, and to get thematically close suggestions for related pages, as in the old sidebar, as the category the current page is in would be extended automatically, once mdn/yari#5547 is fixed/implemented.

The categories in which the properties would be sorted in could be simply taken from the CSS Modules list, as the pages there seem ideal as categories for the Reference>Properties list especially considering that they actually contain indexes of properties already. (Example 1)

It is also worth thinking about merging the Module, Property, and At-rules lists, as they would all share the same categories. (Example 2)
In my Opinion this sorting method is vastly superior over Example 1, though i can see it being a bit less easily assessable - but still way better then the current sorting.

Also the Section the current page is in (Learn CSS/Reference/Guides/etc.) to be situated above all other sections, as the sections above do potentially move the automatically extended Reference>Properties>Category list off the screen otherwise.

Further, are the pages in "Learn CSS" and "Layout Cookbook" not guides aswell? Both of these should be parts of the Guides section, and the whole Guides section needs to be categorized aswell, as currently there are many lists - some of which only contain one page - that should be part of other lists in there instead.

If you don't want to merge the Step-ordered Learn CSS and the alphabetically ordered Guides, at least make the Three types of Guide Lists sublists of one Guide Category. (Example 3)
If done so, the Alphabetical index could be its own page aswell, instead of further bloating the sidebar.

Other Parts of this sidebar are also Sorted Weirdly, and Pseudo-classes and Pseudo-elements are selectors aswell, and should be subcategories of the Selectors list.

Why is it important or useful?

Currently the Sidebar for CSS pages is a huge chunk of bloated lists, some of which are too long to be comfortably scrolled through when looking for something specific. The Reference>Properties list is the worst offender, and it is a chore to find the page you are looking for there, especially if you forgot what a property was called exactly.

I actually forgot that the list was way more useful before, until i found #3827 while looking for already existing duplicates to this suggestion. while i agree that the new sidebar has a better and more consistent style it also removed much of the ease of use and/or helpfulness, as now everything is thrown together in one huge list. Also it is now elementarily different to the sidebars for both Javascript (example) and HTML (example) that both still have the actually related links still directly accessible.

Will the work enable learners or professionals to achieve their goals better?

Yes, having the main element for navigation better structured and more easily assessable can only be good for everyone using it.

Other supporting information

items.content_html:
MDN URL

/en-US/docs/Web/API/Gamepad_API/Using_the_Gamepad_API

What specific section or headline is this issue about?

Multiple sections

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

I could be reading the article wrong but ... stuff like this

Note: The Gamepad object is available on the gamepadconnected event rather than the Window object itself, for security reasons. Once we have a reference to it, we can query its properties for information about the current state of the gamepad. Behind the scenes, this object will be updated every time the gamepad's state changes.

What did you expect to see?

AFAIK This wrong.

#1. While it's true a gamepad object will be provided on gamepadconnected, it's also true that gamepad objects will be provided by navigator.getGamepads

#2. The description above and elsewhere suggests holding on to a reference to the gamepad object and querying it for values. But this fails. In fact, the example code in the article does not do this. It updates the gamepad objects near the end

       controllers[gamepads[i].index] = gamepads[i];

In other words, it's updating the controllers array with a new gamepad object for the same gamepad.

If instead you did this

   // no need to use a new gamepad object if we already have a gamepad object
   // for this controller from the gamepadconnected event
   if (!controllers[gamepads[i].index]) {
      controllers[gamepads[i].index] = gamepads[i];
   }

You'd see the example would fail. At least in Chrome I get a few readings and then gamepad object I was holding a reference too goes dead. Where as if I made sure to get new gamepad objects by calling navigator.getGamepads then the code keeps running.

Let me add, holding on to a reference used to work. I was grabbing some old code that held references and I know worked great when I wrote it 7 yrs ago but suddenly it was not working. I tracked the issue down to this. You can't keep a reference to the gamepad object. You need to take new ones by calling getGamepads

Do you have any supporting links, references, or citations?

No response

No response

items.content_html:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/FormData/FormData

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The docs do not mention that FormData is ignoring input type=submit elements.
That is unexpected. A plain HTML submit of a form will include submit inputs.
This feature is useful to implement multiple different submit buttons.

Specific section or headline?

Potentially add it to "Note: Only successful form controls are included..."

What did you expect to see?

Information about this unexpected behaviour, potentially a "Gotchas" section.

Did you test this? If so, how?

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
  <body>
    <script>
      function handleSubmit(e) {
        e.preventDefault()
        const form = document.getElementById("myForm")
        const data = new FormData(form)
        for (var [key, value] of data.entries()) {
          console.log(key, value)
        }
        return false
      }
    </script>

    <form method="POST" id="myForm" onsubmit="return handleSubmit(event)">
      <input type="text" name="text" value="text" /><br />
      <input type="number" name="number" value="1" /><br />
      <input type="submit" name="submit1" value="Submit1" /><br />
      <input type="submit" name="submit2" value="Submit2" /><br />
    </form>

  </body>
</html>

Slightly different Svelte version in REPL

items.content_html:
What page(s) did you find the problem on?

  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Request/credentials
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Access-Control-Allow-Credentials

Specific page section or heading?

  • Under Syntax > Value for the request credentials page
  • The intro text for the Access-Control-Allow-Credentials page

What is the problem?

There are a few problems:

  1. Explanation on credentials weren't accurate because Authorisation headers were sent regardless whether 'credentials' were set to omit, same-origin, or include.

  1. The Access-Control-Allow-Credentials page mentioned that credentials are cookies, authorization headers, or TLS client certificates.

A few things here:

  1. Access-Control-Allow-Credentials are not required for Authorization headers. They can be sent regardless whether Access-Control-Allow-Credentials is present.
  2. Authorization headers only need Authorization to be included Access-Control-Allowed-Headers.
  3. Access-Control-Allow-Credentials are not required to send cookies between domains and subdomains. This is not listed anywhere but I thought it'll be good to make things clear.

What did you expect to see?

Three things:

  1. I recommend removing "basic http auth" from the request credentials page since it doesn't look correct.
  2. I recommend updating the pages to reflect a more accurate understanding for Access-Control-Allow-Credentials. Not sure what to update at this point, but I can take a stab at it.
  3. Maybe we can point the "etc" part in Request Credentials page to the Access-Control-Allow-Credentials page because they seem linked. I'm not sure whether this is accurate though.

Did you test this? If so, how?

I tested credentials and wrote an article about my tests. I focused on cookies in this article and didn't include the Authorization header parts. There's a test repository included in the article. I can create a test repo for the authorization part if necessary. Just let me know.

MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/AbortController

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

This was missing information about whether calling the controller.abort() function would cause the promise returned from .json(), .text(), (or any of the body-downloading functions on the resolved Request object) to fail with Uncaught DOMException: The user aborted a request. (Chrome's behavior), From experimentation, it seemed that calling controller.abort() would cancel either the request promise or the body promise, so I think that detail should be added to save others the trouble.

Specific section or headline?

2 found pages: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/AbortController and https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/AbortSignal
The section was the Note under the examples on these pages

What did you expect to see?

Details on the promise abortions returned from Response.prototype.text(), or .json(), or others.

Did you test this? If so, how?

Yep, tested chrome console interaction when downloading a large file with Slow 3G network throttling. Test code:

var ctrl = new AbortController();
var res = await fetch('https://www.ledger-cli.org/3.0/doc/ledger3.pdf', { signal: ctrl.signal });
console.log('response received');
var data = await res.text();
console.log('text downloaded');

// ^ Executed the above, then after "response received" and before "text downloaded", manually executed:
ctrl.abort();

// Resultant behavior is that "text downloaded" never was displayed, and we received this:
// (x) Uncaught DOMException: The user aborted a request.

MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/HTMLLabelElement/control

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The documentation explains the control matches the element whose id is provided with the for attribute or null otherwise.
However, the specifications differs somewhat. It states that "If the for attribute is not specified, but the label element has a labelable element descendant, then the first such descendant in tree order is the label element's labeled control."
A 'labelable element' is a "button, input (if the type attribute is not in the Hidden state) meter, output, progress, select, textarea, form-associated custom elements"
Reference: https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/forms.html#htmllabelelement
Thus if we write:

let label = document.createElement('label');
let button = document.createElement('button');
label.appendChild(button);

label.control should give us the HTMLButtonElement, but now in Firefox v95.0.2 it returns null

Specific section or headline?

What did you expect to see?

I expected control to return the first instance of a child labelable element if no for attribute is set.

Did you test this? If so, how?

let label = document.createElement('label');
let button = document.createElement('button');
label.appendChild(button);
label.control instanceof HTMLButtonElement; // label.control returns null

items.content_html:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WritableStreamDefaultWriter

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

Im am referring to this example currently on
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WritableStreamDefaultWriter:

const list = document.querySelector('ul');

function sendMessage(message, writableStream) {
	// defaultWriter is of type WritableStreamDefaultWriter
	const defaultWriter = writableStream.getWriter();
	const encoder = new TextEncoder();
	const encoded = encoder.encode(message, { stream: true });
	encoded.forEach((chunk) => {
		defaultWriter.ready
			.then(() => {
				return defaultWriter.write(chunk);
			})
			.then(() => {
				console.log("Chunk written to sink.");
			})
			.catch((err) => {
				console.log("Chunk error:", err);
			});
	});
	// Call ready again to ensure that all chunks are written
	//   before closing the writer.
	defaultWriter.ready
		.then(() => {
			defaultWriter.close();
		})
		.then(() => {
			console.log("All chunks written");
		})
		.catch((err) => {
			console.log("Stream error:", err);
		});
}

const decoder = new TextDecoder("utf-8");
const queuingStrategy = new CountQueuingStrategy({ highWaterMark: 1 });
let result = "";
const writableStream = new WritableStream({
	// Implement the sink
	write(chunk) {
		return new Promise((resolve, reject) => {
			var buffer = new ArrayBuffer(2);
			var view = new Uint16Array(buffer);
			view[0] = chunk;
			var decoded = decoder.decode(view, { stream: true });
			var listItem = document.createElement('li');
			listItem.textContent = "Chunk decoded: " + decoded;
			list.appendChild(listItem);
			result += decoded;
			resolve();
		});
	},
	close() {
		var listItem = document.createElement('li');
		listItem.textContent = "[MESSAGE RECEIVED] " + result;
		list.appendChild(listItem);
	},
	abort(err) {
		console.log("Sink error:", err);
	}
}, queuingStrategy);

sendMessage("Hello, world.", writableStream);

Preliminary note: Note that then is called multiple
times on the same Promise (branching, not chaining):
defaultWriter.ready.then is called multiple times.

When a write Promise rejects, we see the problems with
the code. Assume the first chunk's write promise rejects:

  • The error handler printing "Chunk error:", err is called
    13 times (not just once for the failing chunk): all
    chunks (their "tasks") are immediately enqueued by
    defaultWriter.ready (not in the writer/stream's queue).

  • The error handler registered for the closing task
    (printing "Stream error:", err) is not called at all.
    The error resulting from calling defaultWriter.close()
    is unhandled. Instead of:

    defaultWriter.close();

    it should be

    return defaultWriter.close();

Specific section or headline?

Section "Examples": https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WritableStreamDefaultWriter#examples

Note that the example might also be here: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WritableStreamDefaultWriter/close

What did you expect to see?

I would love to see an example that:

  • handles errors / Promise rejections decently (handling a single error once, no unhandled errors, handling errors from close, no writing attempts after error)
  • does not use "branching" then when "chaining" then or async/await could easily be used (this example shows the confusion that can arise)

Did you test this? If so, how?

Yes, I tested this. To reproduce:

  • Download the code from "https://mdn.github.io/dom-examples/streams/simple-writer/"
  • reject some Promise (the one already explicitly in the code or add one to reject).
  • Run the code in a browser already supporting WritableStreams.

items.content_html:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CustomElementRegistry/define

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The discussions of the class for a web-component custom element, in particular the examples, is chaotic. Some examples illustrate a class without a constructor() method. Others place all the class action inside the constructor() method. Still others place the action in the connectedCallback() method. The existing examples are inconsistent and full of extraneous code trying to construct goofy giant shadow HTML DOMs.

connectedCallback() is not consistently and well described to show that the custom element may be constructed but not fully parsed to make its innerHTML available. The solution to this is difficult to find; it's in the lifecycle discussion, but nowhere is it explained how this is useful, or why this exists in contrast to constructor().

It is further not explained why element.innerHTML, element.innerText, and element.textContent sometimes exist and sometimes don't within the web-component class constructor.

Are we supposed to use customElements or CustomElementRegistry?

CustomElementRegistry.define() ... Parameters

The second parameter of the define() method needs explanation and examples which are less random. Answer these questions for autonomous elements: is a constructor() containing super() required? What parts of the HTML environment are available in the constructor? Is connectedCallback() required to access the HTML? When is it useful? If parsing is delayed after connection, what is the correct way to wait for it to be done? Are we supposed to await a Promise returned by CustomElementRegistry.whenDefined() ? Its definition is difficult to find and it's not easy to see how it should be used.

What did you expect to see?

I expect to find a web-component spec that states the names and purposes of all the methods and all the callbacks of CustomElementRegistry, in one chapter of the MDN API.

I expect to find short examples that show the correct (i.e., as intended by web-component designers) class definition of new elements, so I don't have to figure this out by trial, error, and stackoverflow.

Thanks.

items.content_html:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Document/getElementById

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

This is a followup to #5124

The link in the bullet point

  • xml:id - has a utility method for allowing getElementById() to obtain 'xml:id' in XML documents (such as returned by Ajax calls)

was updated to point from a broken mdn link to a specification page on w3.org. However, this page doesn't actually have the promised utility method.

The source code that the link alludes to is actually present on the mdn page at internet archive: https://web.archive.org/web/20140408083257/https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/xml/xml:id
the code in question is a simple xpath method:

var getElementByIdWrapper = function (xmldoc, myID) {
        return xmldoc.evaluate('//*[@xml:id="'+myID+'"]', xmldoc, 
                function () {
                  return 'http://www.w3.org/XML/1998/namespace';},
                XPathResult.FIRST_ORDERED_NODE_TYPE, 
                null).singleNodeValue;
};

I'm not sure if it makes sense to include this code in-line on this doc page, for most people it'd probably introduce more confusion, however in my specific case I was actually looking for this code and didn't understand why it wasn't available on the linked w3.org page.

Specific section or headline?

"See also"

What did you expect to see?

A link to some example code to get elements in an xml document based on the xml:id attribute

items.content_html:
What page(s) did you find the problem on?

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/HTMLElement/input_event

Specific page section or heading?

The first sentence:

The input event fires when the value of an <input>, <select>, or <textarea> element has been changed.

And later:

Note: The input event is fired every time the value of the element changes....

What is the problem?

The germane HTML specification is at: https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/indices.html#event-input-input, defining this event as:

Fired at controls when the user changes the value (see also the change event).

But the definition on MDN is more expansive, removing the qualification that changes must be initiated by the user.

For the avoidance of doubt, we are here discussing whether some non-user-initiated change should fire the input event.

What did you expect to see?

It is very possible that MDN is right and this is a mistake in the HTML spec. If so the spec should be updated. But also the MDN page should recognize and explain this difference until it is fixed upstream.

Did you test this? If so, how?

No

items.content_html:
What is the new suggestion?

WebSocket docs are missing the WebSocket.readyState enum properties WebSocket.CONNECTING, WebSocket.OPEN, WebSocket.CLOSING and WebSocket.CLOSED.

Extract from the specification:

interface WebSocket : EventTarget {
  [...]

  // ready state
  const unsigned short CONNECTING = 0;
  const unsigned short OPEN = 1;
  const unsigned short CLOSING = 2;
  const unsigned short CLOSED = 3;
  readonly attribute unsigned short readyState;
  readonly attribute unsigned long long bufferedAmount;
  [...]
}

https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/web-sockets.html#the-websocket-interface

Why is it important or useful?

This would probably need to be 4 short pages. I think this can be done in less than an hour.

Having this info will make it easier for devs to find out these properties exits and lead to better code in the ecosystem.
Not knowing they exit devs might write checks like webSocket.readyState === 1 which is confusing to readers. Devs should be enabled to write webSocket.readyState === WebSocket.OPEN by giving them this info.

Other supporting information

See: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebSocket

My contribution

I'm happy if someone fixes this but I am also willing to do it myself. However, I am unsure where to start.
Is this something that should/would be added to MDN? How are "enum states" like this usually documented? How do I go about creating these pages?
items.title: [html] Content suggestion: WebSocket.readyState enum properties WebSocket.OPEN, WebSocket.CLOSING, etc

items.content_html:
What is the new suggestion?

See this Twitter thread: Now that the potentially-confusing WindowOrWorkerGlobalScope prefix is gone, I suggest adding a one-liner paragraph near the top saying that the global is provided both by Window and WorkerGlobalScope (with links). Something like:

Available as a global in both windows and workers (see Window and WorkerGlobalScope).

Why is it important or useful?

The one good thing about the old prefix was that if you were "in the know," it told you right away whether something was Window-only (like document) or both (like encodeURIComponent).

Other supporting information

We'd make this change on the same set of pages that used to have the WindowOrWorkerGlobalScope prefix. I don't think we need this for Window-only or WorkerGlobalScope-only properties; it looks like they already have a prefix.

I should be able to work on this next week if you'd assign it to me. Any hints on how to approach it, etc., very welcome!

items.content_html:
A big step forward was made in #8351, but I'd like to propose this rule to page naming:

  1. If the item is available on the global, use the name. Eg:
    • ServiceWorkerGlobalScope.skipWaiting becomes skipWaiting.
  2. If the item is typically reached via properties reachable from the global, use that property chain, omitting the global.
    • Document.querySelector becomes document.querySelector.
    • CacheStorage.match becomes caches.match.
  3. If the item is an instance method/property, use the constructor name with the first set of caps lower-cased + the property name.
    • Element.getBoundingClientRect becomes element.getBoundingClientRect.
    • HTMLElement.offsetHeight becomes htmlElement.offsetHeight.
  4. If the item is a static method/property, use the constructor name + the property name.
    • Notification.requestPermission remains Notification.requestPermission.
  5. Otherwise, just use the name.
    • PointerEvent remains PointerEvent

items.content_html:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Document/DOMContentLoaded_event#checking_whether_loading_is_already_complete

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The section "Checking whether loading is already complete" contains this code:

function doSomething() {
  console.info('DOM loaded');
}

if (document.readyState === 'loading') {  // Loading hasn't finished yet
  document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', doSomething);
} else {  // `DOMContentLoaded` has already fired
  doSomething();
}

But isn't this a race condition? If the state switches from loading to interactive after the if condition finishes the check but before the event is fired, the doSomething function will not be invoked.

Specific section or headline?

"Checking whether loading is already complete"

What did you expect to see?

I expect to see one of two things, depending on whether my assessment is correct:

  • If there is a race condition, the code should be revised to prevent it somehow.
  • If there is not a race condition, then the page should document this fact and how we know that readyState cannot change between the if condition check and adding the event listener.

Did you test this? If so, how?

No, I didn't run any testing. I'm not sure how you could test a race condition reliably here.

MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Window/localStorage

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The page suggests that localStorage persists forever.

But then WebKit made this March 2020 announcement https://webkit.org/blog/10218/full-third-party-cookie-blocking-and-more/ that they will automatically clear a domain's localStorage after 7 days where the browser is opened but the domain is not visited.

Specific section or headline?

the stored data is saved across browser sessions.

except that while localStorage data has no expiration time

What did you expect to see?

A clarification note about Apple's stated policy of automatically deleting a domains localStorage if not visited for 7 days when Safari is opened.

Some commentary on this issue:

  • https://www.theregister.com/2020/03/26/apple_relax_were_not_totally/
  • https://ar.al/2020/03/25/apple-just-killed-offline-web-apps-while-purporting-to-protect-your-privacy-why-thats-a-bad-thing-and-why-you-should-care/
  • https://andregarzia.com/2020/03/private-client-side-only-pwas-are-hard-but-now-apple-made-them-impossible.html

These all respond to the announcement, but I'm having trouble finding recent documentation about this issue on MDN or elsewhere.

Did you test this? If so, how?

Not yet. Requires at least 7 days to test, but I can write something up if there's interest.

items.content_html:
mdn/browser-compat-data#9125 is a long discussion about the peculiar cases of Location+WorkerLocation and Navigator+WorkerNavigator, which are the only APIs on the web platform where distinct interfaces are used to represent the "same" thing in window and worker contexts.

For example, navigator.userAgent is available in both window and worker contexts, but navigator itself is a different kind of object. (This difference rarely matters in practice.)

BCD will follow the structure of specs/implementations, but on MDN there's duplication that might be possible to avoid. These pairs of pages and their subpages should be considered for merging or cross-linking:

  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Navigator + https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WorkerNavigator
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Location + https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WorkerLocation

For location it's probably best to keep them separate since the worker variant is read-only. But navigator it's hard to see the usefulness of splits like this:
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Navigator/languages
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WorkerNavigator/languages
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Navigator/locks
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WorkerNavigator/locks
items.title: [html, web-locks] Avoiding duplication/confusion between Location+WorkerLocation and Navigator+WorkerNavigator

items.content_html:
MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WindowOrWorkerGlobalScope/clearTimeout

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

The page says nothing about what happens if clearTimeout is too late, and fails to deactivate a setTimeout operation. In fact, it implies that failure to clear cannot be detected.

Specific section or headline?

Notes

What did you expect to see?

Usually when clearTimeout is issued, the setTimeout function is still in progress. However, there are race conditions where setTimeout is ending just as clearTimeout is issued. If setTimeout has just ended, but not yet been detected or handled, one may want clearTimeout to detect this as an error, but the MDN documentation is unclear as to whether this is possible or not. This can be an important error condition during asynchronous operations where setTimeout is used. Data loss or worse can result if we rely on clearTimeout to prevent a timeout in the rare case when the timeout has just happened, since this case cannot be detected either before or after the call to clearTimeout.

Of course, we can detect that setTimeout resolved much later, and so can eventually know that a call to clearTimeout failed, but only if we know to test for this unusual case. Either way, the documentation could be more helpful.

Did you test this? If so, how?

Asynchronous race conditions hurt my head, and can be very rare, and so I don't know how to test for them.

});

What page(s) did you find the problem on?

A number of docs related to device orientation

Orientation and motion data explained

  • Still marked as draft
  • Does not cover DeviceMotion frame.
  • Explains only the absolute frame, not the relative frame.

Web APIs > Detecting device orientation

  • needs better linking to above doc.

  • Window.ondeviceorientationabsolute - corresponding docs missing. Looks like this is absolute-only version of orientation relative to earth frame, based on compass.

  • Window.deviceorientation_event and Window.ondeviceorientation

    • Marked experimental, but looks like the main API
    • Documented as relative to earth frame, but has absolute and relative value. Various docs indicate it is not standardised and some systems do relative, some absolute. Not clear what relative "means". So basically need to find out what relative means and what systems support what behaviour.

  • Window.orientationchange (also the event). This is the angle relative to the natural device orientation of the screen. So relative to the deviceorientation.

    • Marked as deprecated, but not clear what should be used?
    • There is also Screen.onorientationchange that is also deprecated and FF only.

  • CSS Object Model (CSSOM) > Managing screen orientation - this looks OK but refers to deprecated Screen.onorientationchange

Other relevant docs:

  • Window.devicemotion_event (and friends)
  • Google doc on topic
    Anyway,
  • Chrome 50 info on change that confuses me
  • Pretty cool tute

items.content_html:
What is the new suggestion?

After chromium 89.0.4359.0.
When the event is in the target phase, it will trigger { useCapture: true } listener, and then { useCapture: false } listener. It does not depend on the order they were registered.

Why is it important or useful?

The description in this line:

content/files/en-us/web/api/eventtarget/addeventlistener/index.html

Lines 98 to 102 in 710d917

<p>For event listeners attached to the event target, the event is in the target phase,
rather than the capturing and bubbling phases.
Events in the target phase will trigger all listeners on an element in the
order they were registered, regardless of the <var>useCapture</var>
parameter.</p>

Might confuse someone who never tries this before.
I think we need a more precise document.

Other supporting information

  • Chromium Commit: Fire capture before bubble handlers at target
  • WebKit changes 236002

Thanks for the review !

MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/EventTarget/addEventListener

MDN URL: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Document/drag_event

What information was incorrect, unhelpful, or incomplete?

It is unclear to me how a dragged element is treated by the browser.
I would expect that deleting dragged.parentNode.removeChild would change the demo.
But it seem that dragging an element removes it from its current position in the dom tree.

Specific section or headline?

The fiddle demo contains these lines

      if ( event.target.className == "dropzone" ) {
          event.target.style.background = "";
          dragged.parentNode.removeChild( dragged );
          event.target.appendChild( dragged );
      }

What did you expect to see?

After commenting out dragged.parentNode.removeChild i would expect that there are two dragged-divs the one that was appended and the orignal one that was not removed.

      if ( event.target.className == "dropzone" ) {
          event.target.style.background = "";
          // dragged.parentNode.removeChild( dragged );
          event.target.appendChild( dragged );
      }

Did you test this? If so, how?

Yes i forked the demo on fiddle

items.content_html:
@chrisdavidmills commented on Mon Oct 05 2020

@Kaiido commented on Mon Oct 05 2020

Content Issue

  • Please close this issue, I accidentally submitted it without adding any details
  • New documentation
  • Correction or update

URLs of page you are seeing the problem on:

  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/window/requestAnimationFrame
  • https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/window/cancelAnimationFrame

Details

requestAnimationFrame and cancelAnimationFrame used to be Window only methods, but it has recently been added to DedicatedWorkerGlobalScope too. https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/imagebitmap-and-animations.html#animationframeprovider

interface mixin AnimationFrameProvider {
  unsigned long requestAnimationFrame(FrameRequestCallback callback);
  undefined cancelAnimationFrame(unsigned long handle);
};
Window includes AnimationFrameProvider;
DedicatedWorkerGlobalScope includes AnimationFrameProvider;

I guess the page should now be Web/API/WindowOrWorkerGlobalScope/requestAnimationFrame, but I fear this would break any link to the current /Web/API/window/requestAnimationFrame. So I'm not sure how it should get handled.

Also, compat-data should probably be updated (currently these methods are supported in Blink only).
items.title: [html] requestAnimationFrame is also available in Dedicated Workers
